page.title: Emphasis
page.p: The em element indicates that its enclosed text should be emphasized. You may use em to stress certain words in a sentence. Do not use em to effect a particular typographic style, since it may be rendered differently by different processing tools.

section.title: Processing Expectations
section.p: Emphasized text is traditionally presented in an italic or oblique font. Italic and oblique fonts stress a portion of text without making it stand out. By contrast, bold text tends to draw the eye, which can be distracting when reading long passages of text. In scripts without a distinction between roman and italic type styles, it may still be possible to use an oblique font or some other font variation. Bold text may be used if necessary.

Underlining should be avoided completely, since it hurts the legibility of the text. This problem is especially pronounced in scripts which place diacritical marks below the text. In these scripts, underlining can render the text completely illegible.

section.title: Comparison to DocBook
section.p: The em element is functionally similar to the emphasis element in DocBook. Athough DocBook does not normatively specify a means of controlling the presentation, most DocBook processing tools allow writers to set the role attribute to bold or strong to specify bold text. We explicitly recommend against doing this in Mallard documents and processing tools.
